# 07 - For Loop in C

### Objective

In this challenge, you will learn the usage of the for loop, which is a programming language statement which allows code to be executed until a terminal condition is met. They can even repeat forever if the terminal condition is never met.

The syntax for the _`for`_ loop is:
````
for ( <expression_1> ; <expression_2> ; <expression_3> )
    <statement>
````
- expression_1 is used for intializing variables which are generally used for controlling the terminating flag for the loop.
- expression_2 is used to check for the terminating condition. If this evaluates to false, then the loop is terminated.
- expression_3 is generally used to update the flags/variables.
The following loop initializes __i__ to 0, tests that __i__ is less than 10, and increments __i__ at every iteration. It will execute 10 times.
````
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
	...
}
````
### Task

For each integer _`n`_ in the interval _`[a, b]`_ (given as input) :

- If _`1 <= n <= 9`_, then print the English representation of it in lowercase. That is "one" for __1__, "two" for __2__, and so on.
- Else _`if n > 9`_ and it is an even number, then print "even".
- Else _`if n > 9`_ and it is an odd number, then print "odd".

### Input Format

The first line contains an integer, _a_.<br>
The second line contains an integer, _b_.

### Output Format

Print the appropriate English representation, __even__, or __odd__, based on the conditions described in the 'task' section.

### Sample Input
````
8
11
````
### Sample Output
````
eight
nine
even
odd
````
